Award.AwardTitle: Motion of Uni-Flagellated Bacteria in Visco-elastic Media

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Tang, Jay X.
Proposal Number: 1438033

The goal of the proposed study is to investigate how bacteria interact in a non-aquaeous fluid environment, which is often found in biological fluids. Findings from this work will be applicable to a general set of bacteria that swim using the same basic mechanics and could explain why bacteria in aqueous environments are uni-flagellar while other bacteria are multi-flagellar. Results of this work are important, since microscopic swimmers like bacteria are most often found in body fluids and liquids that are complex and non-Newtonian. There is a need for both data and models in this area, in order to better understand the spreading of decease and ways to stop it. There is also involvement of K-12 students in the outreach part of the project.

The focus of the proposal is on explaining flagellar swimming in viscoelastic media at a fundamental level. In particular, this experimental study will focus on uni-flagellated swimmers and how their motion is different than multi flagellated in viscoelastic media. The approach is to use single flagellum model bacteria in different viscoelastic solutions. The experimental measurements will include quantitative observations of swimming trajectories, speed, and cell body kinematics using optical microscopy techniques. In addition, rheological models will be generated to interpret the experimental results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motion of Uni-flagellated Bacteria in Viscoelastic Media

This NSF funded program aimed at understanding the importance of interactions between swimming bacteria and polymer matrices that create a viscoelastic environment. We used a common species of uni-flagellated bacterium called caulobacter crescentus as a model system, and studied its swimming speed as its surrounding viscosity varies by addition of polymers. The program revealed interesting mechanics and hydrodynamics that account for bacterial swimming.  We measured swimming trajectories, speed, and cell body kinematics using optical microscopy and image analysis techniques. The experimental results are interpreted by modeling the relevant physical interactions, including hydrodynamics and frequency dependent rheological properties of the test media.

 The NSF funded program achieved its educational and outreach goals. Two PhD students in physics received support working on the program. This NSF funded program led to one PhD thesis while contributing to a second thesis in progress. The program yielded five peer-reviewed scientific publications and over a dozen talks and seminars to the scientific communities by the PI and his PhD students. Outreach efforts involved partnerships with K12 schools in the form of offering supplementary lectures, demonstrations, and weekend forums, thereby enriching the science curriculum to local students, including those from less privileged educational and socio-economic backgrounds.
